page.title: 03BRILL WINDMILL,BRICKS,TRAM.
page.content: Brill in the 1086 Domesday Book was called Brunhelle.Brill has a windmill on the common which was built in 1680. It stopped functioning in 1915 but is still open to the public on Sundays. Brill also had some brickworks below the windmill.There were 7 kilns on the common.All but one closed down before the First World War.This was run by William White and lasted for two years longer.The Brill tram ran 7 miles from Tram Hill to Quainton on a single track and worked from 1872 to 1935.A 1339 law protected the forest red, fallow and roe deer.The only other animal was the wild boar.Only a small area of the forest now remains.In 1964 there was a great train robbery.The thieves hid on Letherslade farm and they stole 2,000,000 pounds.Early this century there were 26 shops:bakers, butchers,toy,general stores;now only 5.
